awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites:  LSU Emerging Technology Preparation (LA EMTEC Prep) Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from Louisiana State University (LSU), creates an Innovation Corps Site (I-Corps Site)

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. 

I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

Louisiana State University's (LSU) I-Corps Site nurtures and supports multiple, local teams of faculty, students, and the LSU community that are transitioning their ideas, devices, processes or other intellectual activities into the marketplace. 

The LSU Emerging Technology Preparation (LA EMTEC Prep) program provides training, education, and mentorship to LSU faculty, students, and the community through a six to eight week training program focused on Intellectual Property, the Business Model Canvas, Basics of Licensing and Technology Transfer, Small Business Innovation Research Grants, I-Corps Teams, and other funding mechanisms, Customer Discover and Hypothesis Validation, and Early Stage funding for Research Intensive Companies. Projects can originate from student work, funded or unfunded research at LSU, institutional, or industrial projects. The LA EMTEC Prep program makes LSU technology more competitive in funding programs, as well as increasing the number of new start-up businesses, licensing agreements, and third-party investor reviews stemming from LSU based innovations. 

The LA EMTEC Prep program improves commercialization outcomes for LSU technologies by encouraging researchers (including Post-Doctoral scholar, graduate student, undergraduate, or professional staff) to tackle marketability questions early in their research process and pivot their research accordingly, by training LSU researchers and students on commercialization principles, and by better preparing all parties at LSU to succeed in I-Corps Teams and other intensive assessment programs. Over time, LSU's participation in I-Corps Sites will (1) stimulate the translation of fundamental university-based research into commercially viable technologies, (2) encourage faculty, students, and community-based industry personnel to collaborate around early stage university technologies, and (3) enhance the understanding of faculty, students, and community-based industry partners through hands-on training and experiential learning in innovation and entrepreneurship.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Research and entrepreneurship are deeply intertwined. When professors and students arrive at Louisiana State University, they are here to solve problems, take risks, and overcome challenges. Bridging both disciplines since 2016, the National Science Foundation’s I-Corps program has nurtured 250+ innovators striving towards a common goal: to make an impact.

The impact each participant has made on their respective fields is matched by the impact they’ve made on each other. I-Corps is a community, and many I-Corps alumni have achieved recognition as rockstars in academia. As a result, more and more faculty are thinking beyond publications, towards commercialization.

This is really good for Louisiana; the broader impact is economic development. Twenty-two startups have been created, several have won SBIR/STTR awards, and participants have raised over $7 million for their projects.

Teams that have gone through our I-Corps Site training are now 3X more likely to be funded through LSU’s Proof-of-Concept Fund (up to $75,000 of pre-company formation funding) than those who have not gone through our program. These participants are also 2X more likely to be funded through the statewide Board of Regents Proof-of-Concept Fund, SBIR/STTR program, or PFI award.

Other results are harder to quantify, but just as important. One of I-Corps' big goals is to train an entrepreneurial workforce. For this, graduate students shine. They are leaders, even if they didn't sign up for it. They “learned how to speak the language of industry”, and they mastered the art of networking. Whether they end up in academia or industry, they will be change-makers.

The I-Corps network is a valuable piece of Louisiana’s business infrastructure. It is composed of industry experts, business mentors, program alumni, intellectual property agents, business incubators, etc. Importantly, it touches every major city in the state. It is a privilege to serve our community, and as they say, a rising tide lifts all boats.

I-Corps affects everyone, but it is also deeply personal. Following up with participants after many years is extremely rewarding. You might hear about long-lasting relationships with instructors, visions that did (and didn't) work out, or pivots they wouldn't have made without following the I-Corps methodology. I-Corps tests whether people actually want what inventors make. Many learned a hard but valuable lesson that made them better researchers, better teachers, and better leaders. Many others have dedicated themselves to ideas they validated with I-Corps.

LSU leads the state of Louisiana with 5 strategic priorities striving to enhance Louisiana's talent and economic prosperity.

Agriculture, Biomedical/Health, Coast, Defense, and Energy

These are the intersection of the state's greatest needs, and we are proud that each priority was represented in our I-Corps site. As more time passes, the impact of this award will only increase. Looking towards the new era of I-Corps, LSU is poised to amplify its role in shaping the future of research and entrepreneurship.


Last Modified: 01/02/2025
Modified by: Andrew J Maas
